title: NDIS revolving door heavenly for recruiter Russell Reynolds
text:
The National Disability Insurance Agency made its 2018-19 annual report public on Wednesday.

It was a cycle of tumult and turnover at the agency’s top echelon, with chief executive Rob de Luca abruptly pulling stumps in April. So only naturally, we turned straight to Appendix E: Executive remuneration, the first year that board and key management personnel compensation has been broken out.

Before quitting with immediate effect and joining disability care provider Zenitas, de Luca was drawing an annual salary of $704,689. One of de Luca’s deputies Vicki Rundle became acting CEO (where she remains) on April 30. She was paid $432,168 for the year.

And despite her seniority during two months of higher duties, Rundle was out-earned by her fellow deputy CEO Michael Francis ($453,451), who resigned in July and finished last month; and by Head of Markets Antonia Albanese ($460,120), who joined de Luca at Zenitas in July; and even by her Head of People Hamish Aikman, who took home $481,281. For human resources! If ever an organisational function was ripe for automation…

But she wasn't out-earned by the other deputy CEO Anthony Vella ($427,715), who quit in July and joined de Luca in August.

Yep, four of the NDIA’s eight most senior executives – the CEO included – have left in six months flat. Chaos. What kind of show is chairman Helen Nugent ($158,801) running here?!
